questions.text:
1. Identify the true statement regarding free radicals :

1. Lipid peroxidation of membrane lipids  2. Produced by neutrophils and involved in the respiratory burst 3. Superoxide dismutase inactivates free radicals  4. Occurs in fibrinoid necrosis
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 3 are the correct statements.

Free radicals can cause peroxidation of lipids within plasma and organellar membranes, in the presence of O2. Oxidative damage begins when the double bonds in unsaturated fatty acids of membrane lipids are attacked by O2-derived free radicals, particularly by OH. The lipid–free radical interactions yield peroxides, which are themselves unstable and reactive, initiating an autocatalytic chain reaction known as propagation that can result in extensive membrane damage.

Reactive oxygen species are produced by the rapid assembly and activation of NADPH oxidase, which oxidises reduced NADPH and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion. This oxidative reaction is triggered by activating signals accompanying phagocytosis in neutrophils and is called the respiratory burst.

Superoxide dismutase inactivates free radicals and acts as an antioxidant by converting hydrogen peroxide to oxygen.

questions.text: 2. A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of breast swelling. Her histopathology and mammography findings are shown below. Her aunt developed breast cancer in her 30s. She has a younger sister, 29 years of age, who requires genetic testing. However, she can only afford one test. Which test should be done?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing ducts lined with pleomorphic cells and desmoplastic stromal reaction and microcalcifications on mammography suggests a diagnosis of infiltrative ductal carcinoma. A BRCA1 genetic test should be done.

The BRCA1 genetic mutation accounts for most of the familial breast cancers and hence must be preferred in this case.

The image below shows ducts lined with pleomorphic cells and a desmoplastic stromal reaction in infiltrative ductal carcinoma.



Other options:

Option A: PTEN mutation is associated with Cowden syndrome.

Option C: CDH mutation is associated with Lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Option D: TP53 mutation is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

Pearl PM1878: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated


Pearl PM1183: Cowden Disease

Autosomal dominant

Mutation of PTEN gene on chromosome 10q23.3

Components:

* Hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers

* Intestinal hamartomatous polyp – usually ectodermal, most common in colon

* Facial trichilemmomas – most common feature.

* Cancer of the

* Breast (30–50%)

* Thyroid (10% - Mainly FTC, rarely PTC and Hurthle cell tumors)

* Endometrium

* CNS – 2nd most commonly involved system

* Megalencephaly, ataxia, epilepsy, dysplastic gangliocytoma of cerebellum – Lhermitte Duclos syndrome.

* Developmental anomalies – high arched palate, adenoid facies, prominent forehead, Hypoplastic mandible.

* Skin disease – acral keratosis.

questions.text: 3. A 30-year-old female with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer has been referred for genetic testing. What is the single best genetic test to diagnose the condition?

choices.text: Q PCR for quantification of BRCA1 and BRCA 2 expression levels

questions.solution:
Q PCR for quantification of BRCA1 and BRCA2 expression levels is the single best genetic test to diagnose the condition.

PCR techniques play a very important role in the identification and detection of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. It has attributes such as flexibility, sensitivity, and selectivity that cannot be matched by any other technique in the therapeutic as well as diagnostic arena. It offers screening methods for genetic testing of diseases such as breast and ovarian cancer that offer precise results at relatively low costs, thus allowing many people to access the test. 

Other options:

Option A: Exome sequencing is a type of targeted sequencing, in which hundreds of thousands of custom probes are used to enrich for the roughly 1.5% of the genome that consists of protein-encoding exons before next-generation sequencing. It is not routinely used in the evaluation of suspected germline disorders.

questions.text: 4. Which of the following is not a feature of Turner syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput is not seen in Turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome (45, XO) results from the loss or structural abnormality of one X chromosome in females, leading to gonadal dysgenesis (non-functional ovaries). It is characterised by a short fourth metacarpal, a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and short stature. 

The syndrome leads to primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) due to streak gonads, causing delayed puberty, infertility, and high FSH/LH levels.

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY


 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

* 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 

* 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text:
5. A patient suffers from diabetic kidney disease. Which of the following is not a typical glomerular lesion seen?

GBM - Glomerular Basement Membrane
questions.solution:
Armani-Ebstein lesion is not a typical glomerular lesion seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Armani-Ebstein lesions are characterised by vacuolization and PAS-positive glycogen accumulation within the cytoplasm of tubular epithelial cells that are seen only in severe cases of diabetic nephropathy.

Loss of podocytes, Mesangial expansion, and Diffuse thickening of GBM are typical glomerular lesions seen in diabetic nephropathy. The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Thickening of the GBM occurs in almost all cases of diabetic nephropathy and is best appreciated by electron microscopy. These progressive changes are usually accompanied by mesangial widening and thickening of the tubular basement membranes.

Diffuse Mesangial Sclerosis consists of a diffuse increase in mesangial matrix. The matrix depositions are PAS-positive. As the disease progresses, the mesangial matrix deposits may take on a nodular appearance. Alterations in the GBM lead to disruption in the filtration barrier and loss of podocytes.

Nodular Glomerulosclerosis, also known as intercapillary glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, showing nodules of pink hyaline material in regions of glomerular capillary loops in the glomerulus, is a classical finding. The nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops, known as fibrin caps or adherent to Bowman capsules, known as capsular drops. 

The image below shows Armani-Ebstein lesions (glycogen vacuoles in the tubules).

questions.text: 6. A patient underwent a bone marrow transplant without HLA matching. In which of the following disorders does transplant rejection not occur?
questions.solution:
Transplant rejection does not occur in Bare lymphocyte syndrome.

In a patient with bare lymphocyte disease, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to MHC class II deficiency on the lymphocytes.

Bare lymphocyte disease occurs due to mutations in transcription factors required for class II MHC gene expression. This results in the lack of class II MHC molecules, leading to the impaired development of CD4+ T cells. As these CD4+ T cells are required for both cellular immunity and for assisting B cells, class II MHC deficiency results in a combined immunodeficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Jobs Syndrome occurs due to inherited defects in Th17 responses, leading to chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis and bacterial infections of the skin.

Option B: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is an X-linked disease characterised by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

Option D: Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterised by defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and increased susceptibility to infections.

Pearl PM0536: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: 7. Which is the most commonly inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most commonly inherited bleeding disorder.

VWD is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF). VWF is an adhesive protein that promotes the adhesion of platelets to subendothelial collagen and stabilises factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (type 1 and type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2). The majority have type 1 disease. 

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilia A is the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding.

Option B: Factor V deficiency is a cause of a rare bleeding disorder, known as parahemophilia or Owren disease.

Option D: DIC is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder characterised by the excessive activation of coagulation and formation of thrombi in the microvasculature.

questions.text: 8. Which one of the following is not an aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Bloom Syndrome is not an aneuploidy.

Bloom Syndrome is caused by a defect in DNA repair. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss-of-function mutations in a helicase that is required for homologous recombination repair. It leads to developmental anomalies and an increased risk of developing many different types of cancer.

Aneuploidy occurs due to an error in meiosis or mitosis, and a cell acquires a chromosome complement that is not an exact multiple of 23. 

Other options:

Option B, C and D: Trisomy 13, Trisomy 21 and Klinefelter Syndrome are types of aneuploidy.

Pearl PM1064: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP)

Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

questions.text: 9. Identify the carcinoma most commonly associated with the following finding.
questions.solution:
The given image shows lytic lesions in the skull. Follicular thyroid cancer is most commonly associated with it.

Follicular thyroid cancer spreads hematogenously to bone, lungs, liver, and other parts of the body. Hence, it can lead to lytic lesions in the skull.

Other options:

Option A: Hurthle cell thyroid cancer is a variant of Follicular thyroid cancer, but Follicular thyroid cancer has a greater chance of leading to lytic lesions in the skull.

Option B: Papillary thyroid cancer leads to lymphatic metastasis and doesn't spread to bones hematogenously.

Option D: Thyroid Lymphoma can lead to lymphatic metastasis and doesn't spread to bones hematogenously.

Pearl PM2122: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

* Encapsulated

* Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid

* Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy

* Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

Pearl PM2118: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

* Branching papillae 

* Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk

* Psammoma bodies

* Nuclear changes- 

* Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei

* Pseudo-inclusions

* Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text:
10. Identify the wrong pair:

1. PTEN- Thyroid carcinoma  2. BRCA2 - Prostate cancer  3. P53 - Mucosal neuroma  4. STK 11- Breast cancer
questions.solution:
P53 is not associated with Mucosal neuromas and hence, the wrong pair.

P53 is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which includes oesophageal cancers, sarcomas, breast cancers, leukaemias, brain tumours, and carcinomas of the adrenal cortex.

MEN-2B is associated with RET gene mutation and characterised by neuromas or ganglioneuromas involving the skin, oral mucosa, eyes, respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, and a marfanoid habitus, with long axial skeletal features and hyperextensible joints.

Other options:

Option A: PTEN is associated with Cowden syndrome, which includes breast, endometrial, and thyroid carcinoma and benign skin, gastrointestinal, and CNS growths.

Option B: BRCA2 is associated with Prostate cancer. 

Option D: STK 11 is associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and a high risk of breast cancer.

Pearl PM1878: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated

Pearl PM1137: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

* Known as Sipple’s syndrome

* Chromosome 10 / RET gene

* Associated conditions are:

* Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)

* Pheochromocytoma (>50%)

* Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

* Known commonly as MEN 3

* Chromosome 10/ RET gene

* Associated conditions are:

* Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)

* Pheochromocytoma (>50%)

* Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)

* Mucosal neuromas

* Marfanoid habitus

* Medullated corneal nerve fibers

* Megacolon

questions.text:
11. A post renal transplant patient has respiratory discomfort and pneumonia-like symptoms. The patient has a low CD4 Count. The HPE image is given below. Which of the following stains is not used to stain the organism?

PAS- Periodic Acid-Schiff
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a post renal transplant patient with respiratory discomfort, pneumonia-like symptoms, low CD4 Count, and the histopathological image showing septate hyphae with acute-angle branching, are suggestive of Aspergillus. Congo Red is not used to stain the organism.

Aspergillus can be stained using Gomori Methenamine Silver, PAS and Fontana stain. In invasive aspergillosis, aspergillus can be seen commonly in lung cavities forming fruiting bodies and having septate hyphae that show acute-angle branching.

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic mycosis seen in immunocompromised patients and in patients on prolonged treatment with steroids. This condition starts as pneumonia and later disseminates to other organs.

The image given below shows Aspergillus on Gomori Methenamine Silver stain.



The image given below shows Aspergillus on PAS stain.



Other options:

Option B: Congo Red stain is used for amyloidosis, as shown in the image below.

PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits

Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

questions.text: 12. A child presents with petechiae and ecchymosis. His platelet count is 10,000/mm³, and bone marrow is normal with increased megakaryocytes. What is the next best initial step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with petechiae and ecchymosis, a platelet count of 10,000/mm³, and a normal bone marrow with increased megakaryocytes suggests a diagnosis of Acute Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP). The next best initial step in management in this case is IVIG.

Acute Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is characterised by immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It usually occurs in childhood with equal frequency in both males and females. Symptoms appear 1 to 2 weeks after a self-limited viral illness, which appears to trigger the development of autoantibodies through uncertain mechanisms. An increased number of megakaryocytes can be seen in the marrow. 

It is characterised by bleeding into the skin and mucosal surfaces. Pinpoint haemorrhages (petechiae) are especially prominent in the dependent areas where the capillary pressure is higher. Petechiae can become confluent, leading to ecchymoses. Often, there is a history of easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and haemorrhages into soft tissues from minor trauma. 

Acute ITP is self-limiting and usually resolves spontaneously within 6 months. Glucocorticoids are given only if the thrombocytopenia is severe.

questions.text:
13. For a 65-year-old female with an adnexal mass, CT was done, which showed ascites. What are the true statements regarding the given specimen?

1. Sex-cord stromal tumour  2. Call-Exner bodies 3. Inhibin positive  4. CA-125 level raised
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a female with an adnexal mass, CT indicating ascites, histopathology showing call-exner bodies and the gross image are suggestive of granulosa cell tumour, an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumours made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time, it is seen in post-menopausal women. These tumours are usually unilateral. Hormonally active tumours have a yellow colouration due to intracellular lipids that can be seen on their cut surfaces. On histopathology, Call-Exner bodies are seen, which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

Granulosa cell tumours sometimes secrete large amounts of estrogen, and they may behave like low-grade malignancies. Functionally active granulosa cell tumours in prepubertal girls may produce precocious sexual development. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. Androgens may be produced sometimes by granulosa cell tumours which cause virilization of the patient. All granulosa cell tumours are potentially malignant. The most common mutations are found in the FOXL2 gene.



Other statements:

Statement 4: CA-125 levels are raised in Surface Epithelial-Stromal tumours.

Pearl PM1433: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

* Serous tumors

* Mucinous tumors

* Endometrioid tumors

* Clear cell 

* Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

* Seromucinous

* Undifferentiated carcinoma

II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

* Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor

* Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor

* Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

* Dysgerminoma

* Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Polyembryoma

* Non-gestational choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma (Mature/immature)

* Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

* Pure

* Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary VI. Miscellaneous tumors VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors VIII. Tumor-like conditions

Pearl PM1872: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies

Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

* D: Dysgerminoma

* P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)

* L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: 14. Inflammation associated with caspase-1 is seen in which of the following types of cell death?
questions.solution:
Inflammation associated with caspase-1 is seen in Pyroptosis.

Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

* Activation of the inflammasome complex

* Activation of caspase-1

* Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment

Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation, including leukocyte recruitment and fever. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

* There is cellular swelling

* There is loss of cell membrane integrity

* It is associated with inflammation

* Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved

Other options:

Option A: Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent, distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Option B: Apoptosis: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclear fragmentation.

Option C: Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterised by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. Necroptosis involves two kinases called receptor-interacting protein kinase 1 and 3 (RIPK1 and RIPK3). This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text: 15. Which of the following strains of HPV are more commonly responsible for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18 are considered high-risk types that are commonly implicated in cervical cancer.

HPV 16 and 18 can also lead to vulvar cancer. Condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) is commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11. However, rarely can HPV 16 and 18 cause it, too. 

The E6 protein of high-risk types binds to the p53 gene, while the E7 protein inactivates the pRb gene. p53 and pRb are tumour suppressor genes that, when inactivated, result in uncontrolled cell proliferation. The presence of koilocytes is a histopathological marker of the virus. These cells have a perinuclear halo in the cytoplasm, and these cells disappear when dysplasia advances. 

The image below depicts koilocytes.



Pearl PM2174: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   


 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
